content:
• Friday, December 4, 2015
  • HII

    Huntington Ingalls wins $200M Navy contract for transport

    • Huntington Ingalls (HII +2.4%) says its Shipbuilding unit has won a $200M contract from the Navy for LPD 28, an amphibious transport dock ship.
    • The deal is a cost-plus-fixed-fee advance procurement pact. The initial funds will be used to purchase major equipment with long lead times.
    • The ship will be the 12th amphibious transport dock in the San Antonio class. Ingalls' 10th ship in the class was the lowest-cost when launched, HII says.
    • Previously: Huntington Ingalls appoints new finance chief (Nov. 02 2015)
    • Previously: HII, GD ready to build U.S. icebreakers (Sep. 02 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:22 PM | 1 Comment
  • CHTR

    Cableco capex seen withdrawing as set-top boxes wither

    • The spread of consumer hardware for TV viewing, including Roku devices and Apple TV as well as next-gen gaming consoles, could kill off set-top boxes and ease capex for cablecos.
    • Analyst Craig Moffett sees costs decreasing for major pay-TV providers not only due to the boxes, but also once they complete a transition to next-gen transmission technologies, likely by 2019.
    • Boxes won't go extinct, but the rapid uptake of consumer hardware means the providers will see lower customer premise equipment costs -- in some cases by quite a bit, he argues.
    • "The idea that customers will eventually consume video through their own Apple TV or Roku boxes, or simply connect their cable to their smart TVs, Xboxes and Sony PlayStations, is neither new nor far-fetched," Moffett says. "There are good reasons to believe that CPE spending may come down significantly in future generations."
    • Time Warner Cable (TWC +1.8%) began supporting Roku-only cable service in New York City last month. Assuming its takeover by Charter (CHTR +2.1%) goes through, the combined company's CPE spending could drop to $917M by 2019, from $2.97B this year, Moffett says. Pro forma capital spending at Charter will fall to $5.83B in 2019 from an estimated $6.97B today.
    • He estimates Comcast (CMCSA +1.9%) CPE spending will drop to $1.6B in 2019, from $3.7B this year.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:10 PM
  • MTNOY

    Expensive typo makes $500M difference for Africa's MTN Group

    • Africa's leading telecom, MTN Group (OTCPK:MTNOY -2.1%), has been fighting a $5.2B fine since it was imposed by Nigeria in late October. It won a reduction, but now Nigeria's government says it had a typographical error and the company owes $500M more than it was led to believe.
    • The $5.2B fine would be reduced by 35%, to 674B naira (about $3.4B), according to an "initial" letter to MTN. But Tony Ojobo of the country's Communications Commission said the letter should have read that the discount was 25% -- only to 780B naira (about $3.9B).
    • The original fine came amid a crackdown on unregistered SIM cards, which the country says are used by criminals.
    • Previously: MTN Group CEO resigns over $5.2B Nigerian fine (Nov. 09 2015)
    • Previously: MTN Group falls 2.9% as Nigeria defends $5.2B fine (Nov. 06 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:57 PM | 1 Comment

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: PBY-OLD +6.1%. ETE +2.7%. SPLS +3.2%. VNR +3.1%. SUNE +1.7%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25 p.m.: CMG -7.7%. ATW -4.3%. TMO -3.1%. HZNP -1.7%. CLX -1.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:44 PM | 8 Comments
  • PBY-OLD

    Icahn discloses 12.1% Pep Boys stake, wants Auto Plus deal; shares +11.2%

    • Carl Icahn has disclosed a 6.56M-share (12.12%) stake in Pep Boys (NYSE:PBY-OLD), while declaring the company to be "an excellent synergistic acquisition opportunity for Auto Plus." Auto Plus, an auto parts/services provider, is an Icahn Enterprises subsidiary.
    • Shares have jumped to $17.44 after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 4 Comments
  • GTN

    Alaskan firm tries to squelch Gray Television station buy

    • Alaskan cableco GCI is asking the FCC to stop Gray Television (GTN +2.3%) from acquiring KYES TV in Anchorage, saying Gray will get too much control by buying that and NBC affiliate KTUU at the same time.
    • Gray agreed to buy KTUU as part of a $442.5M deal for Schurz Communications TV and radio stations, and separately agreed to pay $500K for KYES, but asked the FCC for a "failing station" designation so it could merge the two stations.
    • For its part, Gray calls the request "speculative nonsense" and says GCI dominates the state's communications business already.
    • Alaska's attorney general, Craig Richards, is lining up with GCI, saying his office has serious concerns about the failing-station request: "Competition is fragile in the Alaska broadcast market.
    • After hours, GTN is up another 2.1%.
    • Previously: Gray Television paying $442.5M for Schurz TV, radio stations (Sep. 14 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:06 PM
  • JNJ

    Johnson & Johnson wraps deal for biopharma Novira

    • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ +2.1%) says it has wrapped the acquisition of Novira Therapeutics, the privately held biopharma developer of hepatitis B antivirals.
    • Terms weren't disclosed. The company is being integrated into Janssen's Infectious Disease & Vaccines Therapeutic Area.
    • Novira's lead candidate, the orally administered NVR 3-778, is in Phase 1b clinical trials.
    • Earlier, Barclays had launched coverage of JNJ with an Overweight rating and $115 price target; shares closed today up 2.1% to $102.91.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:54 PM
  • NSC

    Canadian Pacific 'disappointed' in NSC bid rejection, plans call

    • In a response to Norfolk Southern (NSC -1.1%), Canadian Pacific (CP -4.6%) says it's "disappointed" with the former's rejection of its $28.4B takeover bid.
    • "CP takes exception to the claims, misdirection and mischaracterization of its offer and the benefits such a combination would provide to customers, shareholders, the industry and the public," the company said in a statement.
    • It plans to hold a conference call Tuesday to discuss the proposed transaction, and "address all concerns about timely regulatory approval raised by NS and correct every inaccuracy."
    • Earlier, NSC said it wouldn't accept the "low-premium, non-binding, highly conditional" proposal, as inadequate and too risky.
    • After hours: NSC -2%; CP +0.1%.
    • Previously: Rail sector hit after Norfolk Southern rebuff of CP Rail's bid, BofA downgrades (Dec. 04 2015)
    • Previously: Norfolk Southern passes on Canadian Pacific offer (Dec. 04 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 7 Comments
  • CMG

    Chipotle issues Q4 warning, rescinds 2016 same-store guidance; shares -5.5% (updated)

    • Assuming recent sales trends continue in the wake of the E.coli outbreak, Chipotle (NYSE:CMG) now forecasts Q4 comparable restaurant sales will be down 8%-11% Y/Y, restaurant margins will be in a range of 22%-24%, and EPS will be in a range of $2.45-$2.85 (well below a $4.09 consensus). (8-K filing)
    • October comparable sales were positive in the low-single digit range, while November sales fell 16%.
    • Chipotle is rescinding its 2016 comparable sales guidance. "In light of recent sales trends and additional uncertainty related to the E. coli incident, we cannot reasonably estimate 2016 comparable restaurant sales at this time."
    • Shares have fallen to $530.06 after hours, after having underperformed in regular trading following news E.coli cases have been reported in 3 more states.
    • Update: To soften the blow, Chipotle has launched a $300M buyback. At current levels, that's good for buying back 1.8% of shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:30 PM | 46 Comments
  • MORN

    Morningstar raises dividend 16%, buyback program by $300M

    • After a solid day traveling with the market following a strong jobs report, Morningstar (MORN +2%) is down 2% after hours after it hiked its dividend and its buyback authorization.
    • The company raised its dividend 16%, to a quarterly $0.22, with a dividend payable Jan. 29. It expects to issue three more dividends in 2016.
    • Meanwhile, a $300M increase to its repurchase authorization brings the total to $1B. Year-to-date, the company has bought back about $92M worth.
    • Still remaining under the current up-to-date authorization is $381M worth of room.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:26 PM

  • Weekly ETF Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: GDX +10.33%. GDXJ +7.52%. TAN +6.96%. SIVR +3.32%. SLV +3.04%.
    • Losers: AMJ -10.69%. GAZ -9.73%. FCG -9.15%. OIL -5.37%. VDE -4.73%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:19 PM
  • CMG

    Chipotle underperforms after E.coli outbreak linked to 3 more states

    • The CDC states seven more E.coli cases have been reported for the outbreak linked to Chipotle (CMG -0.8%) restaurants, including cases involving people in Illinois, Pennsylvania, and Maryland. Of the three most recent illnesses reported in November, only one involved a person (became ill on Nov. 10) who reported eating at Chipotle in the week before his/her illness began.
    • As of Dec. 2, 52 infections have been reported from 9 states - the other six are California, Oregon, Washington, Minnesota, Ohio, and New York - and 20 people have been hospitalized. The majority of the illnesses came from Washington and Oregon, and 47 of the 52 ill people reported eating at Chipotle the week before their illness started.
    • The CDC is still trying to figure out which ingredient caused the outbreak. Chipotle, which has already said it will tighten its food-safety standards, fell modestly today in spite of a 2.1% S&P 500 gain. Shares were down as much as 5% at one point before bouncing.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:09 PM | 5 Comments
  • LLL

    Reuters: L-3 near $550M deal to sell services unit to CACI

    • L-3 Communications (LLL +2.7%) is exclusively talking with CACI International (CACI +1.2%) about selling its government services division, National Security Solutions, and a deal for around $550M is imminent, Reuters reports.
    • The agreement could be announced as soon as next week, sources said., though negotiations are confidential.
    • L-3 shares have gained 18.5% over the past three months. For its part, CACI closed at $101.64, a bit below Tuesday's 52-week high of $104.09; it's gained 34% over the past three months.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:08 PM
  • SDRL

    Seadrill enters new total return swap agreement covering 4M shares

    • Seadrill (SDRL -7.2%) slides to record lows after settling a total return swap agreement expiring yesterday and entering into a new swap agreement with exposure again to 4M common shares as the reference asset.
    • The new total return swap agreement expires March 3, 2016, and the reference price is NOK49.60/share ($0.26).
    • The swaps are typically popular with hedge funds because it provides them with the potential capital gains of owning a large equity stake in a company without needing to put that asset on their balance sheet and with a relatively small cash outlay.
    • SDRL fell alongside another big drop in oil prices today, which undermined most energy-related stocks.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM | 3 Comments
  • JBLU

    With oil prices facing more pressure, airlines rally

    • OPEC's decision to maintain production levels -- and put more pressure on oil prices -- is boosting a fuel-dependent sector as airline stocks rally.
    • Outstripping market gains today: United Continental (UAL +3.8%); Delta Air Lines (DAL +3.2%); and American (AAL +3.9%), as well as smaller carriers. JetBlue (NASDAQ:JBLU) is up 3.4% and Republic Airways (RJET) is up 3.5%. Hawaiian Holdings rose 2.8% and Spirit (NASDAQ:SAVE) is up 3.4%.
    • Meanwhile, Southwest (LUV +4.4%) and Alaska (ALK +5.4%) have hit new all-time highs.
    • The airlines are building on some strength from earlier in the week driven by traffic trends.
    • Previously: Crude oil closes below $40, no relief in sight for oil industry pain (Dec. 04 2015)
    • Previously: Stock futures tilt negative as crude oil slides (Dec. 04 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 7 Comments
  • ATW

    Barclays: Little reason for optimism in offshore drillers but Atwood upgraded

    • Barclays sees little reason for optimism among offshore drilling contractors despite recent outperformance, particularly in light of recent guidance from major oil companies for dramatically reduced offshore spending in 2016; the firm expects another leg down in stock performance as a lack of contracting activity and a massive oversupply of floaters looks daunting in light of the spending cuts.
    • Nevertheless, Barclays upgrades Atwood Oceanics (ATW -5.8%) to Equal Weight from Underweight with an $18 price target, and now considers the stock fully valued after dropping ~23% over the past three months; the firm sees the most downside to Transocean (RIG -3.4%), Diamond Offshore (DO -3.5%) and Noble Corp. (NE -4.6%), while Pacific Drilling (PACD -5.6%) and Ocean Rig UDW (ORIG -4.1%) show the most upside but also come with the most risk with little equity remaining and looming liquidity issues.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 7 Comments
  • KCG

    JPMorgan looking to replace KCG Holdings as its market maker

    • At issue was KCG's performance during the market panic on Aug. 24, when JPMorgan's (NYSE:JPM) stock price dropped by as much as 20% before recovering.
    • The bank has informed the NYSE of its intention to replace KCG, reports the WSJ, and a number will be interviewed next week. KCG will have the opportunity to reapply for its job.
    • The news today was enough to send KCG lower by nearly 6% at one point, but - like JPMorgan on that day in August - KCG has recovered and is currently flat on the session.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:47 PM
  • XOM

    Crude oil closes below $40, no relief in sight for oil industry pain

    • U.S. crude oil settled 2.7% lower at $39.97 and Brent fell 1.9% to $43 after OPEC decided to roll over its policy of maintaining crude production in order to retain market share - a not unexpected outcome but one that offers no relief in sight for the oil industry's pain.
    • "OPEC not cutting is going to put more pressure on oil prices," and the pressure on companies’ spending will feed through into their investment in increasing their production, says Jefferies equity analyst Jason Gammel. “It’s not as though they’ll shut down existing production, but over time their output will decrease."
    • Don’t expect prices to stabilize until low prices force curtailments of pumping in the U.S., which will not happen until the end of next year, Goldman Sachs analyst Damien Courvalin.
    • Energy stocks (-0.7%) are the only S&P industry sector to decline, as the rest of the market has rebounded from yesterday's drop; some of the big oils - XOM +0.3%, CVX +0.6% - have inched higher, and refiners are mostly higher, but it's another down day for most: DVN -1.2%, CLR -5.9%, MRO -2.3%, HES -1%, COP -0.8%, EOG -0.7%, APC -2.4%, ETE -9.3%, ETP -3.5%, EPD -2.4%, WMB -6.9%.
    • ETFs: USO, OIL, XLE, UCO, UWTI, VDE, ERX, OIH, SCO, XOP, BNO, DBO, OTC:DWTI, ERY, FCG, DIG, GASL, DTO, DUG, BGR, USL, XES, IYE, IEO, IEZ, DNO, FENY, PXE, PXI, PXJ, FIF, OLO, SZO, NDP, RYE, FXN, OLEM, DDG
     
     
     
     
    | 3:25 PM | 150 Comments
  • SQBG

    Sequential Brands wraps buyout of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia

    • As expected, Sequential Brands (SQBG +1%) has wrapped its acquisition of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia (MSO +2.7%).
    • MSLO shareholders had signed off on the merger Wednesday.
    • The company asked the NYSE to suspend trading and delist its common stock.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:02 PM | 4 Comments
  • NSC

    Rail sector hit after Norfolk Southern rebuff of CP Rail's bid, BofA downgrades

    • Railroad stocks are broadly lower following Norfolk Southern's (NSC -1.2%) sharp rebuke of Canadian Pacific Railway's (CP -4.5%) takeover bid "at any price" and a BofA Merrill Lynch negative research note on the sector.
    • CEO James Squires tells Bloomberg that NSC execs “haven’t talked to a single customer that supports the idea" of merging with CP, and that “our customers’ responses range from highly skeptical to vehemently opposed."
    • Citing volume declines and weak trends that look to continue into 2016, BofA downgrades CSX (CSX -1.3%) and Union Pacific (UNP -1.2%) to Neutral from Buy, as the firm remains negative on rails with significant coal exposure, and cuts Kansas City Southern (KSU -1.5%) and Genesee & Wyoming (GWR -5.3%) to Underperform from Neutral; the firm lowers KSU due to its growth premium in an environment of slowing growth and cut GWR due to its commodity exposure.
    • BofA reiterates its Buy rating on Canadian National (CNI -1.2%), citing CNI's significantly lower coal exposure, robust intermodal share gains and attractive risk/reward returns.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:57 PM | 13 Comments
  • DRWI

    DragonWave up 41.2% on strong volume

    • Beaten-down DragonWave (NASDAQ:DRWI) is up strongly on volume of 2.35M shares, soundly above a 3-month daily average of 409K. No major news has hit the wires.
    • The gains come three days after the RF backhaul equipment firm announced a Jan. 26 special meeting to lay the groundwork for a reverse split. Shares -84% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:46 PM | 1 Comment
  • FENG

    Phoenix New Media sets new ad deal with lending site

    • Phoenix New Media (FENG -1.9%) has entered into an advertisement cooperation deal through its Tianying Jiuzhou unit with Beijing Phoenix Lilita.
    • Lilita, mainly involved in person-to-person lending and crowd-funding, will place Internet ads on sites and mobile apps that Tianying Jiuzhou operates.
    • Tianyingi Jiuzhou has a 5% stake in Lilita. The deal amends a prior cooperation deal, covering ad services not to exceed HK$4.8M annually (about $619K); business growth means that cap is no longer effective.
    • The cap is being raised to HK$17.5M ($2.3M) for 2015, HK$38M ($4.9M) for 2016, and HK$57M ($7.4M) for 2017.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:55 PM
  • AABA

    Mizuho: Yahoo should sell core business, to Comcast

    • As Yahoo (YHOO) wraps a few days of deliberations over its future amid speculation about whether it should focus on its core or its Alibaba stake, Mizuho is weighing in definitively: Sell the core Web business, and sell it to Comcast (CMCSA +2%).
    • "It remains unclear if the IRS will tax the spin-out of Aabaco, but in our view, a taxed transaction on a likely $3-$5b sale of the core Yahoo business outweighs the risk of the company/shareholders being hit with a $20b IRS tax bill on a spin-out of Aabaco," write the firm's Neil Doshi and Sam Phan. "We think the best option for Yahoo would be to sell its core biz to a strong strategic buyer –- namely Comcast."
    • The two cited four reasons for targeting the media/telecom giant as a buyer: First, skepticism that Yahoo can pull another turnaround; Comcast's existing digital assets; ad assets at Yahoo complementary to Comcast's ad business; and Comcast's strong ability to absorb a deal (with $25B in annual EBITDA, Comcast could retain debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 2:1).
    • Previously: WSJ: Alibaba unlikely to buy core Yahoo business (Dec. 03 2015)
    • Previously: Media companies linked to circling pack around Yahoo Internet business (Dec. 02 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:28 PM | 2 Comments
  • VALE

    Vale plans Valemax ship sale, leaseback that could fetch $1.1B

    • Vale (VALE -4.4%) plans to sell its 11 remaining Valemax iron ore carriers and lease them back in transactions that could raise $1.1B, CFO Luciano Siani tells investors at a conference in London.
    • Each ship is more than 1180 feet long and can carry 380K-400K metric tons of iron ore, and are among the biggest vessels afloat.
    • The CFO also says the company has enough flexibility on its balance sheet to pay a “small dividend” in 2016, but a final decision will be taken by the board when it meets to review year-end accounts.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:15 PM | 5 Comments
  • TMUS

    Cowen: T-Mobile stock hits holding pattern as issues pile up

    • T-Mobile stock (NASDAQ:TMUS) is up with a strong market today, +1.8%, but it's down about 15% from the time of the company's Q3 earnings report, and Cowen & Co. attributes that to a "laundry list" of concerns hitting the stock.
    • Cowen's Colby Synesael lowered the firm's price target for T-Mobile to $42; shares are currently trading at $35.19. The firm maintains an Outperform rating on the stock.
    • T-Mobile is gaining subscribers, but not for free: Marketing costs have gone up with the company throwing out $200 incentives (in billing credit to Sprint customers who switch, or in discounts to high-end iPhones for AT&T's customers).
    • The company's concerns include "issues with the quarter itself; recent pricing/promo actions by Sprint and itself; and, even more recently, anticipated 2016 EBITDA," Synesael says.
    • "Investors will need to remain patient as it's not clear that the stock will make any notable run in front of the (auction)."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:11 PM | 4 Comments
  • VMEM

    Violin Memory falls to new lows as Maxim offers subdued M&A commentary

    • Two days after Violin Memory (VMEM -10.5%) posted an FQ3 miss, declined to provide sales guidance, and stated it has begun a strategic review, Maxim Group's Nehal Chokshi estimates the flash array vendor's IP is worth ~$2/share (for reference, Violin currently trades below $0.90). However, he also thinks Cisco and SanDisk, two firms seen as potential suitors, "have probably moved on by now," leaving Hitachi as the most likely buyer.
    • Chokshi: "[W]e continue to believe there is value in Violin’s IP, as it is the only flash-optimized asset that has: 1) logical unit number (LUN)-selectable data-efficiency capabilities; and 2) high-end array data availability/durability capable of continuous data protection and stretch clusters ... the customer set between Violin and Hitachi meshes well, and the spend for Hitachi would be easily manageable."
    • Shares are now down 34% since the FQ3 report came out, and 82% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 4 Comments
  • KITE

    Kite Pharma showing weakness ahead of ASH presentations; shares off more than 20% since mid-November

    • Displaying unsettling weakness ahead of The American Society of Hematology's annual meeting in Orlando (Dec. 5-8), Kite Pharma (KITE -3.6%) is down again today, albeit on light volume. Shares have lost 22% of their value since peaking at $89.84 on November 19.
    • According to ASH's website, the company is cited in 40 oral and poster abstracts that will be presented during the conference.
    • One abstract details the results from a Phase 1 safety study, ZUMA-1, to determine dose-limiting toxicities (DLT) in patients with refractory aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma who were treated with the company's lead product candidate, KTE-C19 (paper #3991). Six patients received a target dose of 2M anti-CD19 CAR T cells/kg after a fixed dose of conditioning chemotherapy regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine. Two subjects experienced grade 1 toxicities (mild) while three had grade 3 reactions (severe, but not life-threatening). All were reversible within three days. The sixth subject, however, experienced a DLT of grade 4 (life-threatening, urgent intervention required) encephalopathy and grade 4 cytokine release syndrome (cytokine storm). The patient died within 30 days of of KTE-C19 cell infusion due to an intracranial hemorrhage judged to be unrelated to KTE-C19 by the investigator. Of the three subjects assessed for response at one month post infusion, two achieved complete responses and one achieved a partial response.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 1 Comment

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: LIVE +61%. DHRM +36%. OTC:CALI +16%. RLYP +16%. YECO-OLD +16%. IDT +15%. ATV +15%. ULTA +13%. PXLW +11%. GCO +10%.
    • Losers: OTC:MDVX -21%. THST -21%. BKS -19%. NVIV -18%. FCEL -17%. NRG -17%. CTIC -14%. SB -14%. RYAM -13%. WG -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:44 PM | 2 Comments
  • VLO

    Another strong year ahead for refiners, analyst says

    • Credit Suisse analyst Edward Westlake says favorable market conditions that drove the oil refining business this year will carry over into next year, making many refiner stocks strong buys.
    • Global gasoline demand grew at 3x its historical rate in 2015, and while consensus expectations for gasoline demand predict a regression closer to the long-term trend in 2016, Westlake sees at least another year of strong demand growth remaining.
    • The analyst says he has been surprised at Q4 performance so far , and predicts a 2016 environment conducive to earnings strength, especially among coastal names.
    • Credit Suisse has Outperform ratings on these refiners: VLO +1.6%, NTI +0.5%, CLMT +1.5%, MPC +3%, TSO +1.2%, ALDW -2.3%, WNR +1.6%, PBF +0.2%, DK +1.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:41 PM | 23 Comments

  • Goldman's euro bear rethinks position

    • "Today [Thursday] was not the most fun day I’ve ever had," said Goldman Chief Currency Strategist Robin Brooks, after the euro zoomed 3.1% higher following the ECB policy statement and press conference. "What’s clear is the meeting sent a very confusing message."
    • Among the most bearish on the euro on the Street - he sees the common currency falling to $0.95 in a year - Brooks had predicted a "dovish" surprise from Mario Draghi, but instead got a nominal cut in the deposit rate and only an extension (not a boost) to QE. The euro erased a month's worth of losses in one session (it's given back about one-third of that gain today). It's currently at $1.0839.
    • "We badly misread this meeting ... Even in the unlikely event that today’s disappointment was a mistake, we think it has cost enough credibility that the euro-down story we had envisaged is now less likely to play out."
    • ETFs: FXE, EUO, ERO, DRR, EUFX, ULE, URR
     
     
     
     
    | 12:39 PM | 4 Comments
  • EA

    EA +4.8%, rebounding on look at life beyond 'Star Wars'

    • Electronic Arts (EA +4.8%) is bouncing back from some early Star Wars game worries as investors and analysts start to look beyond its latest release and to what looks like a packed slate ahead.
    • Today, Atlantic Equities has bumped its rating on the stock to Overweight, from Neutral. It has a price target of $84; that implies more than 19% upside from a current $70.47.
    • Piper Jaffray this week warned "Don't get overly focused on one title," as worries mounted about early performance of Star Wars: Battlefront. Speaking as part of a Credit Suisse investor conference, EA's COO Peter Moore pointed to am "embarrassment of riches" coming to the lineup as soon as April, when the company's fiscal 2017 begins.
    • "We've got some of our core franchises; a new Battlefield coming up, a new Mass Effect title coming up; we actually kick off the year with Mirror's Edge Catalyst, which we pushed out of FY 16 and into FY 17 ... And we also have Mass Effect Andromeda from our BioWare studio. And Plants vs. Zombies: Garden Warfare 2 is shipping in Q4 of this year."
    • He had skipped over mentioning the company's annual sports tentpole titles as well as a new Titanfall coming during fiscal 2017 as well.
    • Previously: Cowen sees strong videogame holiday, with Activision its top pick (Dec. 02 2015)
    • Previously: EA +1.1% as Piper Jaffray looks beyond 'Star Wars,' urges buying on weakness (Dec. 02 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:38 PM
  • KMI

    Kinder Morgan expects 2016 DCF OK to support dividend growth guidance

    • Kinder Morgan (KMI -12.7%) says it has completed its 2016 budget process and expects to generate 2016 distributable cash flow of ~$5B, which would be sufficient to support dividend growth in the 6%-10% range discussed in its Q3 earnings call.
    • KMI says it will construct its 2016 plan to maintain an investment grade rating with all three agencies, and does not plan to issue equity at current prices.
    • KMI says its board will review the dividend policy and financing plans in coming days and will announce the policy and plan when finalized.
    • The company's attempt to reassure investors and stem this week's ~20% loss is not working so far, as shares have dipped to lows of the day.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:25 PM | 157 Comments

  • Best session for gold in two months

    • The news is commodity bearish today - a solid employment report assures a rate hike this month and OPEC will continue to run strong production into a glutted market.
    • Gold, however, is enjoying a bounce after falling in a near straight line for the last six weeks. The metal touched as low at $1,050 yesterday when new ECB stimulus measures disappointed. A 2.4% rise in today's session has gold back up to $1,087 per ounce.
    • GLD +2.2%

  • CHK

    Jakab: Chesapeake investors should be relieved, as chance of financial distress reduced

    • Yesterday's selloff in Chesapeake Energy (CHK -4.4%) after the company said it would look to buy back some of its debt is a knee-jerk reaction to a sign of financial distress rather than a cool analysis, Heard On The Street's Spencer Jakab writes.
    • Combined with CHK's move in July to eliminate its dividend to conserve cash, the company has enhanced its odds of riding out the energy storm as a going concern, and the most recent move does not cost shareholders a cent, according to Jakab.
    • "Shareholders should be feeling buoyant, not despondent," Jakab writes. "By swapping for the nearer-term debt, Chesapeake lowers the chance of it facing a debt crisis and shareholders being wiped out."

  • AMBA

    Ambarella erases post-earnings losses; Street looks beyond GoPro (updated)

    • After opening lower due to the soft FQ4, FQ1, and FY17 guidance provided with its FQ3 beat, Ambarella (AMBA +0.4%) has reversed course, as market decide (for now at least) the bad news is priced in following a 55% drop from the video processor firm's July peak. A 1.3% Nasdaq gain is likely helping.
    • Canaccord's Matt Ramsay, a long-time bull, insists Ambarella's growth story remains intact. He reiterates his view (previous) that the company's IP will allow its video processors to maintain a competitive edge relative to general-purpose SoCs, and that growing demand for HD/UltraHD video capture and compression across a slew of end-markets will drive growth.
    • Chardan's Marc Estigarribia maintains a Hold, but also has a $90 target (well above current levels). He sees IP security camera, automotive aftermarket camera, and drone market strength helping to offset GoPro-related weakness. Needham's Quinn Bolton (Hold) offers a similar view. "[W]e remain on the sidelines as we monitor sell-through data for wearable sports cameras. Outside of wearable cameras, we are encouraged by AMBA's traction."
    • On the earnings call (transcript), CEO Fermi Wang stated the launch of three new SoC families during the quarter boosted design win activity across markets, and that drone-related processor sales "were enjoying significant revenue increases driven primarily by sales of our 4K or UltraHD camera SoCs."
    • CFO George Laplante stated IP security-related sales rose Q/Q and Y/Y, with U.S. consumer strength helping offset Chinese weakness, and that auto aftermarket sales grew with the help of strong Asian demand. He noted high customer inventories in the sports camera market (i.e. at GoPro) are expected to have a big impact on FQ4 and FQ1.
    • Prior Ambarella coverage
    • Update (2:34PM ET): The recovery didn't hold: Ambarella is now down 3.7%.

  • CLR

    Bloomberg: Continental "could have made $1B more by doing nothing"

    • Continental Resources' (CLR -5.6%) move in October 2014 to liquidate its insurance against an oil market crash just before prices collapsed wound up costing the company $1B this year, Bloomberg calculates.
    • Believing the downturn would not last, CLR’s Harold Hamm liquidated all the company’s oil hedges, including contracts locking in prices for 2014 and 2016 production, reaping a one-time gain of $433M; if Hamm had been right and oil prices rebounded, CLR would have enjoyed the cash windfall from selling the hedges plus higher prices for its crude, but prices plunged instead.
    • "He made the move thinking things are going to improve and they didn’t," Wunderlich's Jason Wangler says. "It was a calculated gamble and it didn’t pay off."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:35 AM | 1 Comment

    • Vale (VALE -3.5%) CFO Luciano Siani says the best way to settle claims and fund the cleanup following the deadly dam disaster at the Samarco mine would be to bring Samarco back into operation, adding that "we have an understanding attitude on the part of the bondholders that the best way to pursue is to try to bring the company back.”

  • GNVC

    GenVec up again after favorable patent ruling

    • Thinly traded nano cap GenVec (GNVC +22.8%) is up big again in early trading on more than double normal volume, albeit on turnover of only 56K shares. The stock has almost doubled in the past two days in response to its announcement that it received a Notice of Allowance (NOA) from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office for its patent application "Affenadenovirus (Gorilla) or Adenoviral Vectors and Methods of Use."
    • The allowed claims cover composition of matter for its proprietary adenovectors isolated from mountain gorillas, including potential adjustments and additions that may be introduced to engineer the vectors for optimal performance in a range of therapeutic and vaccine applications. The value proposition of gorilla vectors is that most people lack pre-existing immunity to them.
    • Chief Scientific Officer Douglas Brough says, "Our data suggest these gorilla vectors outperform other adenovectors, including those derived from serotype 5, when used for molecular vaccines. High and durable antibody and T cell responses to encoded antigens from a single administration have been observed in our preclinical studies. GenVec's gorilla vectors are showing promise in other gene therapy and nucleic acid delivery applications as well."
     
     
     
     
    | 10:05 AM

  • Treasury yields moving higher as solid jobs reports assures rate hike

    • In addition to the November jobs gain of 211K (vs. 200K expected), October's big 271K number was revised higher to 298K, and September's 137K to 145K.
    • The average workweek edged lower by 0.1 hour to 34.5 hours. Average hourly earnings rose $0.04 to $25.25; on a Y/Y basis, they're higher by 2.3%.
    • The labor force participation rate gained 10 basis points to 62.5%. A year ago, it was 62.9%.
    • The broader U-6 unemployment rate rose to 9.9% from 9.8%. One year ago, it was 11.4%. Headline unemployment held steady at 5%. One year ago, it was 5.8%.
    • The 10-year Treasury yield is moving higher again, up three basis points to 2.35%, and the 2-year Treasury yield is up a big 3.3 basis points to just under 1%.
    • TLT -0.75% premarket
